intro: Pseudocherleria charadzeae, commonly known as the Georgian bellflower, is a rare and endemic plant species native to the mountainous regions of Georgia. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its bell-shaped, blue or purple flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or forested areas at high altitudes, showcasing adaptations to its harsh environment. Its leaves are lanceolate and covered in fine hairs, while its stems are erect and often branched. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a vulnerable species in its native range.
